E es fayt de ferr de India , e semblantment cove que totas las causas que havem ditas de rasoris e de inscissoris e de serras.	And it is made of Indian iron, and similarly all the causes we have said of razors and of incissors and saws.
De inscizio extremitatz e de la serratura dels osses.	Of cutting ends and of the sawing of bones.
Las extremitatz se poyresso o per causa intrinseca o per causa extrinseca, o cum tu auras medicat aquela corrupcio per curacio de aquelas medicinas e la curacio no comfereys, o vezes la corrupcio anar deves le membre la qual no percuteys denguna causa, lahoras cove que tu inscidas aquel membre entro aquo la hon acossec la corrupcio, per que le malaute evasesca per aquo de mort o de malicia que es major defeliment del membre.	The ends become swollen or due to an intrinsic cause or an extrinsic one, or when you have treated that corruption with those medicines and the treatment does not confer, or when the corruption goes away from the member which has not been cut for any reason, then you should cut that member where the corruption is located, in order that the patient escapes by death or wickedness, which is a greater defect of the member.
E le senhal de aquel al qual accideys, es que·l membre es fayt negre entro que sia cujat que foc la ja comburit, o se poyreys aprop la negror entro que la poyredura aquela ane entro aquel membre que siec lu e que prengua tot le cors; e donc coyta te am inscizio de aquel.	And the sign of that to which it happens is that the member becomes black when it is cooked that fire has scorched it, or it swells soon the darkness within that the burning, then bind that with an incision of that.
E semblantment si es causa de la corrupcio percussio de alcunas causas venenosas ayssi cum de scorpio mari o de vupera o de rutela e de semblantz.	And similarly if the cause of the corruption is a blow from some venomous causes like that of scorpion stings or of a snake or of a centipede or of similar ones.
E si la corrupcio o la percussio es en la extremitat del dit, lahoras tu inscideys le dit e no dones spazi a la corrupcio per que ane entro a la ma.	And if the corruption or the blow is in the end of the finger then you should cut the finger and do not give space to the corruption that it goes into the hand.
E semblantment si accedeys a la ma, lahoras tu inscideys aquela de la razit del focil, e no dones spazi a la corrupcio entro que prengua en le focil del bras.	And similarly if it affects the hand then you should cut that from the knuckle of the firebone, and do not give space to the corruption so that it goes into the firebone of the arm.
E si envezeys aquel, lahoras inscideys le bras entro al coyde en la junctura.	And if instead you cut the arm within the cuff in the joint.
E si passa otra la corrupcio e la vezes enviro le coyde, lahoras en aquel es la mort del malaute; e aministrar autra causa otra aquo en curacio es quantitat de vertut.	And if another corruption goes and turns around the cuff then there is the death of the patient; and add another cause in treatment it is amount of virtue.
E semblantment fay del pe quan corrupcio envezeys le dit del pe, lahoras tu inscideys aquel entro ad un dels nozes.	And similarly cut the foot when corruption happens instead of the toe of the foot then you should cut that within one of the toes.
E si pren en la pente del pe, lahoras tu inscideys tot le pe.	And if it is taken in the leg, then you should cut into the entire leg.
Mays si pueja entro al denol, lahoras tu inscideys la camba entro a la junctura del denol.	But if it goes into the groin, then you should cut into the leg up to the joint of the groin.
E si la corrupcio ja es pervenguda sobre le denol, lahoras en lu no es engen sino dimissio, e layssar le malaute a la mort.	And if the decay has already reached the groin, then there is nothing to do but to release the patient and let him die.
E la manieyra de inscidir le membre o de serrar lu es que tu strenhas le liament en la partida pus dejos la qual voles inscidir, e strenh autre liament sobre le loc; e extenda le ministre un liament a las partidas dejos, e extenda le ministra autra liament en sus; e tu separa la carn la qual es entre dos liamentz ain spatum lat entro que sia descuberta tota la carn; e aprop sia inscidit o serrat.	And the way of cutting or binding a member is that you should tighten the ligament at the part lowest where you want to cut, and tighten another ligament above the location; and extend one ligament to the parts below, and extend another ligament above it; and separate the meat which lies between two ligaments so that there be exposed all of the flesh; and then let it be cut or bound.
E cove que sia pausat drap de li de totas partidas per so que no toque le loc sa, e que vengua al malaute lesio ajustada e apostema caut.	And cover that which is bound with linen cloth from all sides so that it does not touch the wound, and let the patient have a poultice of boiled linseed, and let the wound be cauterized.
Mays si accideys flux de sanc quan obras, lahoras tu cauteriza le loc coytadament, o pausa sus lu alcunas polveras restrenhentz le sanc; e aprop retorna a la tua medicacio entro que sia complida.	But if blood flow happens when you operate, then you should cauterize the wound carefully or place upon it some powders that constrict the flow of blood; and then return to your treatment until it is complete.
E aprop lia le membre plaguat am liament al u convenient, e cura aquel entro que sia sanat.	And then ligate the wounded member in a way convenient, and cure it until it is healed.
E yeu recomti a tu aquo que endevenc a un home en le sieu pe, aquest meteys accident le qual yeu e a tu recomtat, le qual es quar accidic a lu negror en le sieu pe am adustio que era asemblada a combustio de foc.	And he also told me of an incident that happened to a man in his foot, the same accident which I and he recounted, which is that it turned black on him in his foot due to a scorching that was like fire burning.
E aquela corrupcio accidic primierament en le sieu dit entro que tendec tot le pe.	And that decay occurred first in his toe, spreading throughout the entire foot.
E adonc aquel home preparec per si meteys pus que vic la curacio anar al membre am la vehemencia de lu que atrobec de dolor e de adustrio de lu, e el inscidic aquel pe entro a la junctura, e foc sanat.	And then that man prepared remedies for himself before he went to see the doctor, the vehemence of his pain and burning increasing; so he cut off that foot at the joint, and it healed.
Lonc temps accidic a lu aquela meteyssa corrupcio en le dit de la ma indic.	That man had that decay in the toe of his hand for a long time.
E adonc venc a mi, e so me perforsat repercutir aquela superfluitat am aquo que pausegui sobre la ma de las medicinas, aprop la mundificacio del cos de lu; e no es repercussa la superfluitat e comensec anar al autra dit entro que comensec en la ma.	And then he came to me and requested that I reflect upon that excess of medicine which had been applied to his hand, so that the cleansing of his body might be accomplished; and if the excess is not reflected and begins to go into the other toe, it will begin in his hand.
E el apelec me a inscidir la ma de lu, e yeu no volgui far aquo sperant sobre la repercussio de aquela superfluitat, e mays que temegui deves la inscizio de la ma de lu mort, quar la vertut del malaute era sobre cazement.	And he implored me to cut off his hand, and I would not do so hoping for the reflection of that excess, but fearing that the cutting off of his hand might result in death, for the strength of the patient was great.
E pus que el se desperec de mi, es retornat en la sua terra e pervenguec a mi que aquel home preparec e inscidic la sua ma tota, e es sanat.	And when he despaired of me, he returned to his own land and it happened that the man prepared and cut off his entire hand, and healed.
E no he adhuzida aquesta narracio sino per que sia adjutori sobre aquo que catz de aquesta malautia, e que sia significacio per la qual sia significada e segon la qual sia obrat.	And I have not added this narrative except that it be an assistant for whoever suffers from this disease and that it be a sign by which they are recognized and how they are treated.
De cura sinuum et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	Of the cure of sores and the quality of enemas with medicines.
Quan accideys apostema en alcus membres carnozes e·l spazi de l’apostema es prolonguat entro que fa colleccio de sania, e aprop es romput e perforat, e es eyssida de lu la sania, e roman le loc vuoyt quays cum si era vayssel, e la codena que es desobre lu ayssi cum drap subtiliat, e no es pervengut a deriera corrupcio, e no inprimeys en le os o en nervi ni en liament, es apelat sinu, e no es nompnat fistula.	When there is an abscess in some fleshy member and the space of the abscess is prolonged so that it forms a collection of pus, and then it is broken and perforated, and the pus is discharged from it, and the place is hollow as if it were a vessel, and the membrane which is above it with a thin cloth, and there has not arrived at further decay, and it does not press upon the bone or nerve or ligament, it is called a sinus, and is not named a fistula.
Mays empero si le spazi es prolonguat entro que la corrupcio enprema en alcun membre, lahoras es appelada fistula e no zukem.	But if the space is prolonged so that the decay infiltrates some member, then it is called a fistula and not a sinus.
E la cura de lu es que inscidas aquela codena tota ayssi cum es revolvut, e majorment quan es subtiliada e es fayta cum drap, e comfizas que no adhereys al loc per la sua corrupcio.	And the cure for it is that you cut off all of that membrane as it is rolled up and more so when it is thinned out and done with a cloth, and that you do not let it adhere to the location by its decay.
Mays si tu speras que la codena adheresca e que aquela corrupcio no aja conseguit per deriera consecucio, e en la codena ha spassitut de cara, lahoras tu cura aquel am clisteri.	But if you fear that the membrane might adhere and that decay has not been accomplished through subsequent consequence, and the membrane is hollowed out on its face, then you should cure it with enemas.
E es que consideras al sinu, e lahoras si es gran, e·l brac que yeys es de fetent odor, lahoras clisteriza aquel am medicament egipciac le qual es de oli e vi agre e ziniar recebent partidas enguals, e sian ajustadas en un vayssel, e sian coytas sobre le foc entro que’l medicament se fassa rog e pervengua a specitut de mel.	And it is that you consider the sinus and if it is large and the membrane that you see has a foul odor, then cleanse that sinus with Egyptian medicine which is of oil and sour wine and honey received in equal parts, and they are poured into a vessel and boiled over the fire until it becomes like honey.
E aprop tu pren de lu aquo que es necessari e dissolveys lu am aygua e mel; e clisteriza am aquel le sinu, e strenh le orrifici de lu, e layssa la medicina en lu per la quantitat de doas horas.	And then take from it what is necessary and dissolve it with water and honey; and cleanse it with that sinus, and tighten the orifice of it, and let the medicine remain in there for the quantity of two hours.
E aprop extratz aquela am sprecio; e fay aquo per tantz dias entro que sia mundificat le sinu e sia remauguda la pudor.	And then extract that with caution, and do this for several days until the sinus is cleansed and the odor eliminated.
E alcunas veguadas es clisterizat am aygua de cendre, quan no es a tu prezent aquest medicament; e es que tu prenguas la cendra de vitz, e met sobre lu aygua; e aprop cola aquela e clisteriza aquel am ela entro que te confizes que·l sinu lahoras es ostat.	And sometimes it is cleansed with water of ashes when that medicine is not available to you; and it is that you take the ashes of wood, and put upon it water, and then strain that and cleanse that sinus with it until you are convinced that the sinus has been cleared.
E si le malaute no ha tollerancia sobre le medicament egipciac ni l’aygua de la cendre, lahoras clisteriza aquel am aygua e mel e quays sia mesclat ziniar trissat, e clisteriza aquel am vi e mel mesclat, quar de proprietat de mel es que mondifique e lave, e le vi fa adherir le sinu, e majorment quan en le vi ha superfluitat de stipticitat e de siccitat.	And if the patient has no tolerance for Egyptian medicine nor ash water, then cleanse it with water and honey mixed with ground-up honey, for honey cleanses and washes, and wine makes the sinus adhere more especially when there is excess of dryness and stinging.
E cum tu fas aquo alcunas veguadas e te comfizes que·l sinu ja es remaugut, lahoras clisteriza aquel am aquo que fa naysser la carn en lu.	And when you have done this several times and are convinced that the sinus is cleansed, then cleanse it with that which makes the flesh grow on it.
E es que prenguas de enguent dyafinicon e dissolveys aquel am oli rozat e vi stiptic; o que clisterizas aquel am alcunas medicinas e enguentz autres que hajan las proprietatz les quals ja he yeu scritz en le tractat dels enguents.	And it is that you take the medicine called diafinicon and dissolve that with oil of roses and stinging wine; or that you cleanse that sinus with some medicines and other unguents which have the properties which I have already written in the treatment of the unguents.
E si le orrifici del sinu es streyt en le qual no es recebuda la canula del clisteri, lahoras tu le amplifique aquel am ferr petit a petit, e pausa en lu calgua envolopada en enguent egipciac o en enguent basilicon entro que sia amplificat.	And if the orifice of the sinus is narrow and the cannula of the enema cannot be received, then you should enlarge that with a small iron tool little by little, and put into it a sponge wrapped in Egyptian unguent or in basil unguent until it is enlarged.
E semblantment si le orrifici es ample, lahoras tu agregua las labias de lu am sutura e layssa de lu quantitat en la qual intre le clisteri ses addicio.	And likewise if the orifice is wide, then you should draw in the edges of it with a stitch and leave in there the quantity in which the enema is added to it.
E si le orrifici de lu del qual corr le brac es elevat a las partidas desus, lahoras secca aquel en le pus bas loc que es en lu per que le brac corra entro dejos, quar quan le brac es coartat en la preondeza de sinu la carn esser en lu engendrada.	And if the orifice from which the membrane hangs down is elevated to the parts above it, then dry that in the pus-filled location beneath it so that the membrane is generated in there because when the membrane is constricted in the sinus the flesh is generated in there.
E si no es a tu possible seccar le sinu entro al enviro del os pus bas segon que voles, lahoras te perforssa que prepares le membre am preparacio per la qual corr de lu le brac leugierament segon que es a tu apparelhat e que no sia en lu retengut alcuna causa del brac.	And if you are unable to dry it within the bone of the pus-filled location beneath it according to what you want, then be assured that you prepare the member with preparation by which the membrane hangs down loosely according to how you have perceived it and so that nothing in there retains the membrane.
E pren medicinas consolidativas que sian pausadas sobre le sinu convenientz ad aquo que vols exxten aquelas sobre drap de li.	And take medicines that are solidifying which are placed over the sinus conveniently according to what you want so that they extend those upon thin linen cloth.
E le drap sia de tan gran quantitat cum fa la comunicacio de tot le sinu; e aprop inscidey am las forfexs en le dreyt del orrifici del sinu un trauc pus ample un pauc que l’orrifici del sinu; e aprop exten sobre autre drap de li dels enguentz leons segon la quantitat del trauc, e pausa le sobre aquel per posicio longinqua del orrifici del sinu per que sia aleujat le eyssiment del brac de lu e no ostes le drap gran sino aprop alcus dyas una veguada.	And let the linen cloth be of such great quantity as to make contact with all the sinus; and then cut off with the forceps on the right of the orifice of the sinus a wound more ample a little than the orifice of the sinus, and then extend over another linen cloth of the unguents of lions according to the quantity of the wound, and place that upon it in such distant position from the orifice of the sinus so that the discharge of the membrane be removed from there and not press upon the linen cloth a great deal but after some days once.
Mays aquel que es sobre le orrifici del sinu, le qual remauguas en tota hora per so que yesca aquo que es ajust en lu del brac.	And that which is upon the orifice of the sinus and which dries up every hour because it exudes what is constricted in there of the membrane.
E per que sapias si aquo que corr de lu del brac es mot o pauc, o es digest, o es no-digest.	So that you can tell if what comes out of his arm is blood or pus, or is digested or undigested.
E am aysso tu considera le loc de aquel sinu, si en lu sent le pacient dolor o no, e si es en lu apostema.	And also consider the location of that vein, whether it hurts in that spot, and if there is an abscess there.
E cum la tua medicacio es prolonguada en la tal manieyra, e vesas la matiera que es gitada sobre le orrifici del sinu ja adhereys, o se apropria adherencia, lahoras le mayti tu le deslia o le tertz dia, e quan deslias la plagua, lahoras muda le drap per autre e renova le enguent.	And after your treatment has been going on for some time in this way, and you see that matter coming out from the opening of the vein that has become attached or is sticking to it, then on the third day you loosen it, and when you loosen the dressing, then change the cloth with a new one and renew the ointment.
Mays si del sinu aprop lon spazi yeys virus subtil, lahoras no te desperes de la adherencia de li, quar la sanacio de lu se apropria, quar so alcus homes en les quals tarda generacio de carn en las lors plaguas, e de aquels so en les quals es fayt le contrari de lu.	But if the vein is too deep for you to see the virus subtil, then do not be desperate about the adhesion of it, because its healing is just right, because there are some people in whom the generation of flesh happens slowly under their dressing, and there are some whose opposite happens.
E si del sinu aprop motz dias es yssit brac indigest, lahoras sapias que·l sinu no adhereys; e si es tardada la adherencia del sinu e es la causa prolonguada, lahoras tu ajusta en exsiccacio de las medicinas, e si las medicinas so humidas en lor substancia e en la sua vertut, son seccas ayssi cum enguent dyafinicon, quan es en lu ajustada superfluitat de addicio de zegi.	And if after many days the arm is not digested, then you should know that the vein has not become attached; and if its adhesion is delayed and it becomes the prolonged cause, then you should put it in the exsiccation of medicines, and if the medicines are moist in their substance and in their power, they are dried like a dyaphoretic ointment, when there is added excess of white vitriol.
E le mays derier am le qual es curat, es que prenguas de enguent dyafinicon e sia dissout en oli rozat, e sia sobre lu vojat vi antic engual en la sua substancia, e aprop comfeys aquel am lu, e usa de aquel.	And the best way to cure it is that you take a dyaphoretic ointment and dissolve it in rose oil, and put vinegar with it in its substance, and then comfort it with it, and use it.
E ja fa semblant en aquela accio, quan no y a brac, enguent dyafinicon, mel quan es coyt entro que sia engrossat, e usa de lu; o que prenguas mirra e aloen e enses, e trissa tot e polveriza sobre le mel quan es sus le foc, e aprop lineys aquo sobre drap e strenh aquel sobre le sinu; e lineys aquel am le mel le qual has cuoyt entro que es engrossat, e polveriza sobre drap e strenh aquel.	And when there is no arm, then you take the dyaphoretic ointment, mix it with honey and use it when it is cooked until it thickens; or you take myrrh and aloe and cook them together, and triturate both until they are powdered over the honey that has been cooked over the fire, and spread this on a cloth, and put the cloth on the vein; and you powder that which you have cooked with honey over a cloth, and spread it on.
E alcunas veguadas so administratz am lu aristologia longua e razitz de lili celesti (e es lili celesti) e farina de errs e centaurea, e usa de aquels simples o ajustatz, trissa aquels e cribela e polveriza sobre le mel le qual he recomtat; e husa de lu.	And some times it is administered with a long aristology of celestial lily (which is the lily celestial) and thistles of the earth and centaurea, and you use these simples or adjust them, triturate them, sieve and powder them over the honey that I have recommended; and use it.
E si es prolonguat le sinu, e no es sanat per aquesta curacio, lahoras sapias que la corrupcio es en le preon de lu, e ja fa enquisicio en les osses o en les autres membres durs o als liaments; lahoras tu le cura am curacio fistular, ayssi cum desus es dit.	And if the vein is prolonged and not healed by this treatment, then you should know that corruption is in its depth, and it already makes inquiry into the bones or other hard parts or to the tendons; then you treat it with a fistular treatment, as above is said.
De curacio de panarici et unguis attritae et incisione digiti additi et sectione.	About the treatment of panaric and worn nail and added cutting of the finger and section.
Panarici es apostema le qual nays dejos la ungla del dit pous de la ma o del pe, e fort leu nays en les autres ditz, e cum es prolonguat e la sua curacio es mens prezada, o es apostemat de apostema caut, o es corrumput, e gieta brac entro que corrodeys la razitz de la ungla, e fort leu corromp aquela tota, e fort leu perve la sua corrupcio al os entro que es a lu odor fetent, e es fayta la extremitat del dit lada, e la color de lu es fayta fusca.	Panaric is an abscess which forms under the fingernail of the finger of the hand or of the foot, and it usually occurs in other fingers, and when it is prolonged and its cure is less valued, then it is an abscess of cauterized abscess, or is putrefied, and it causes a wound between the roots of the nail, and it rots very much, and its corruption goes to the bone inside which has a foul odor, and the extremity of the finger becomes lopsided, and its color becomes brown.
E donc quan tu auras aquel am aquo que havem dit en la divisio e no comfereys la tua curacio, lahoras cove que tu inscidas am ferr tota la superfluitat que es romasa de la ungla e aprop cauteriza la plagla aprop aquo, quar cauteri mot es juvatiu en aysso.	And so when you have this which we have said in the division and do not comfort your cure, then you should know that you pierce all the superfluity that has been rotted from the nail and then cauterize the wound there with iron, because hot cautery is beneficial in it.
Mays si le os es sa e la ungla es sana, e las addicios de la ungla vuoydas ja compremen las carns a las partidas dedintz, e comensan lu punger e ledeysso aquela, lahoras cove que tu pauses ray subtil dejos le angle de la ungla que pungeys la carn, e impelleys aquela sus e inscideys aquela carn am facilitat, e pausa sobre aquo que roman de la carn de las medicinas comburentz corrosivas entro que sia tot remaugut; e aprop cura aquel am enguentz entro que sia sanat.	But if the bone is healthy and the nail is healed, and the parts of the nail are pressed together by the flesh to the joints within, and they begin to sting and hurt it, then you should know that you put a thin ray below the angle of the nail which pricks the flesh, and push it upwards and cut that flesh with ease, and put on that which comes from the flesh of the corrosive medicines until all is removed; and then cure it with ointments until it is healed.
Mays si la corrupcio ja enprem en le os, lahoras cove que tu inscidas le os aquel e le extraguas, car nul temps no es sanat que sia en lu le os corrumput.	But if the corruption has already entered into the bone, then you pierce that bone and extract it, because it will never be healed as long as there is a腐了骨。
E si vezes la corrozio e la corupcio anar en le dit, lahoras tu inscideys aquel en un dels nozes segons que es premesa la sua rememoracio, e aprop cura aquel entro que sia sanat.	And if you see the rot and corruption going into the finger, then you pierce it in one of its joints according to which is pressed by memory, and then cure that until it is healed.
Mays si a la ungla endeve percussio o atricio, e endeve en aquela dolor vehement, lahoras cove que tu al comensament fleubotomes le malaute, e aprop secca la ungla am spatum agut am seccio transversa desus en jus, e guarda te que la seccio no pervengua entro a la carn que es dejos la ungla, quar tu faras accidir al malaute dolor vehement, e sira causa a nativitat de la carn ajustada superflua en le loc; e aprop cura aquel loc am aquo que ceda dolor.	But if the nail is struck or hit, and it feels violent pain afterwards, then you should know that you should begin by bleeding the patient, and then dry the nail with a sharp spatulum, making a transverse cut on it above, and be careful that the cut does not go into the flesh under the nail, because you will cause violent pain to the patient, and so will cause the generation of superfluous flesh in that spot; and then cure that spot with something that gives relief from pain.
Mays dit ajustat, le qual es nat en las mas de alcus homes, fort leu es carnos tot, e fort leu so en lu osses, o fort leu es en lu ungla.	But a finger joint which is born in the hands of some people is very fleshly, and it is very bone, or it is very nail.
E alcus de lu son natz en la razit de la junctura, o es la nativitat de lu en alcus nozes dels ditz.	And some are born in the root of the joint, or its birth is in some joints of the fingers.
Mays aquel que es nat en alcus nozes del dit no se mau, e aquest que es nat en las juncturas fort leu es maugut.	But that which is born in some joints of the finger is not harmed, but that which is born in the joints is very harmed.
E de aquels que son natz carnoses, la seccio es leugiera, e es que tu inscidas aquel deves la sua razitz am spatum lat.	And of those which are born fleshy, the cut is easier, and it is that you pierce that behind its roots with a broad spatula.
Mays de aquel que es nat en la razitz de la junctura, la curacio es dificil; e donc guarda te de la abscizio de lu.	But of that which is born in the root of the joint, the cure is difficult; and so beware of its incision.
Mays en aquel que es nat en dit deves les nozes, cove que tu inscidas al comensament la carn de lu am inscizio redonda entro al os, e aprop serra am una de aquelas serras convenientz ad aquo, e aprop cura aquel entro que sia sanat.	But in that which is born in the finger between the joints, you should know that at the beginning you pierce the flesh of it with a round incision into the bone, and then cut with one of those convenient saws for it, and then cure it until it is healed.
Mays consolidacio la qual accideys als ditz entre lor motas veguadas o per nativitat del home que nays enayssi, o per consolidacio de plagua o per combustio de foc, o per semblantz, adonc cove que secces aquela consolidacio entro que les ditz retorno a la sua forma natural.	But hardening which happens to the fingers between their joints many times or by birth of man who is born in them, or by hardening of plague or by burning fire, or likewise, therefore you dry that hardening until the fingers return to their natural shape.
E aprop pausa entre lor draps de li enfuzes en oli rozat per que no sian consolidatz leugierament, e separa entre aquels, o pausa entre aquels una lamina de plom subtil entro que sia consolidat segon que cove.	And then spread between their bandages which are soaked in rose oil so that they are not hardened easily, and separate between them or place between them a thin sheet of lead according to what is proper.
E semblantment si accideys consolidacio en alcus ditz am la palma, lahoras tu secca aquela consolidacio segon que es preparada e conveneys a la figura del membre.	And likewise if hardening happens in some fingers with the palm, then you dry that hardening according to how it is prepared and suits the shape of the member.
De inscizio de vices, so son varicas.	Of an incision of wounds, thus are varices.
Vices so son varicas, e so venas envolutas grossas plenas de superfluitatz melencolicas las quals veno en motz dels membres del cors, e le major adveniment de lor en las cambas, e majorment en las cambas dels itinerantz e dels laborantz e dels portantz.	Varices are thus, and so are thick wrapped veins full of melencolic superfluities which come in movements of the parts of the body, and their greatest occurrence is in the legs, and most of all in the legs of travelers and workers and carriers.
Adonc cove que tu administres purguacio del cors de colera negra alcunas veguadas am expulcio fort, e aprop sangna le pacient de la vena basilica.	Therefore you should administer a purgation of the body from black cholera several times with strong expulsion, and then let the patient bleed from the basilic vein.
Mays la curacio de lor am ferr es segon dos manieyras: la una es que sia inscizas e sia atirat aquel sanc negre, e l’autra manieyra es que sia elevada la vena e sia extrayta tota.	But their cure by iron is according to two manners: the one is that it is pierced and that black blood is drawn, and the other manner is that the vein is elevated and all of it is extracted.
La seccio de lu es segon aquesta manieyra: embroca al comensament la camba am aygua cauda mot entro que le sanc gros sia resolvut, que es feculent de la camba, e aprop strenh la camba del malaute a la partida pus sobirana de la coyssa entro a la partida dejos del denol am una benda, e aprop secca la vena en un loc, o en dos, o en tres am seccio ampla, e aprop eleva le sanc negra am la tieua ma de la partida dejos de la camba entro en sus, e desus en jus, entro que del sanc sia yssida la quantitat que voles e que vezes habastar, e la qual tollera la vertut del malaute.	Its cut is according to this manner: at the beginning moisten the leg with hot water until the gross blood is dissolved, which is feculent of the leg, and then tighten the leg of the patient at the part above the pus-superior of the thigh to the part below the pubic bone by a bandage, and then dry the vein in one spot, or two, or three with broad cuts, and then elevate the black blood with his own hand from the part below the leg up inside until he has come out the quantity that you want and that he can bear, and which tolerates the vertue of the patient.
E aprop lia aquela, e comanda a lu que abstengua de las viandas colera negra engendrantz.	And then tie it up, and command him to abstain from foods that generate black bile.
E itera la curacio per fleubotomia quan las venas so umplidas e aquo notz al malaute.	And repeat the treatment by phlebotomy when the veins are filled and it is noticed in the patient.
Mays la elevacio de lor es segon aquesta manieyra: tu que razas la camba del malaute, si en lu so motz pels, e aprop met le en banh e embroca la camba de lu am aygua cauda entro que s’enrogesesca e las venas sian exuberadas; o que sia exercitat per exercici fort, si banh no es a tu present, entro que·l membre sia scalfat.	But the elevation of them is according to this manner: you raise the leg of the patient, if in him there are veins, and then put him into a bath and embrocate his leg with hot water until it reddens and the veins become prominent; or that he be exercised by vigorous exercise, if a bath is not at hand, until the member becomes warm.
E aprop secsa la codena en le dreyt de la vena per seccio en le lonc o en le derier de lu deves le denol, o en le pus bas de lu deves lo talo.	And then cut off the thread on the side of the vein either in the long or behind him, depending on where the pain is, or in the lowest part of him, depending on where the foot is.
E aprop uobre la codena am uncis e excorja la vena de tota part entro que appara al sentiment, e es deves la appericio de lu que vezes aquela roga declinant a negror.	And then open the thread with tweezers and scrape the vein all around until it appears to feeling, and the appearance of it that you see turns black.
E donc cum evazeys e de la codena tu vezes aquela blanca quays sia corda.	And when you have finished with the thread, you will see that it has turned white as a cord.
E aprop tu met dejos aquela le ray entro que sia elevada e sia gitada de la codena, e sospen aquela am onci orp leon.	And then you put down that which is beneath the thread so that it is elevated and is dripped from the thread, and suspend it with a silk thread.
E aprop secsa autra seccio aprop aquela seccio per tres ditz, e aprop excorja la codena de la partida desus de la vena entro que apparia.	And then cut another section below that section with three fingers, and scrape the thread from the top of the vein until it appears.
E aprop eleva aquela e inscideys aquela en deriera seccio deves le talo, e aprop extratz aquela e eleva aquela entro que sia yssida per la seccio segonda, e aprop extratz aquela de la seccio que es sobre aquela.	And then elevate that and insert it into the second section behind the foot, and extract it from the section that is above that.
E fay aquo entro que extraguas aquela de la seccio que es pus sobirana o pus auta de totas las seccios, entro que tota es yssida; e lahoras inscideys aquela.	And do this until you extract it from the section that is highest or highest of all the sections, so that all are extracted; and then insert it.
E si no obezeys a tu ad extrayre e elevar, lahoras intromet una agulha am fiel fort doble e ligua aquela e extratz la, o intromet dejos lu le ray e revolveys la tua ma a tota part entro qu’en sia getada.	And if he does not obey you and extract and elevate it, then insert a strong bent needle and thread that and extract it, or insert it underneath the leg and rotate your hand all around so that it is dripped.
E guarda te que no sia inscidida; quar si es trencada, es fayt a tu dificil elevar aquela mot e es vengut sobre le malaute per aquela nocument.	And be careful that it is not cut, for if it is broken, it is difficult for you to elevate that vein and it has come upon the patient through that harm.
E cum aquela tota auras fora-gitada, lahoras pausa sobre le loc de la plagua lana submerssa en vi e oli rozat e oli no-rozat, e cura aquel entro que sia sanat.	And when all of it has been completely dripped out, then put over the site of the wound wool soaked in wine and rose oil, and cure that until it is healed.
E si la vit es contrayta havent tortuositat a la qual sia envolucio a las partidas, e no es segon rectitut segon que havem dit, lahoras cove que tu fendas sobre aquela a tota partida de tortuositat de lu e als locs de envolucio de lu, e aprop suspen aquela am uncis entro que eleves aquela tota.	And if the vein is contracted having tortuosity at which is wrapping around the parts, and it is not according to rectitude as we have said, then know that you must split that all along its tortuosity, and suspend it with tweezers until you elevate it all.
E guarda te deves la tua seccio que no inscidas la vena e que no plagues aquela, quar dificil sira a tu elevar aquela; e serva la tua prudencia en aquela.	And be careful that you do not cut the vein and harm it, for it will be difficult for you to elevate it; and use your discretion in that.
Forma del inscident am le qual es seccada vit:	The shape of the incision with which the vein is dried:
Forma de unci orp:	The shape of a silk thread:
No es a lu accuitat ayssi cum als uncis ni es de aguda extremitat per so que no plague la vena; e es de grossa flexibilitat leon, quar si era subtil, inscidira la vena per la sua subtilitat; habantz es en lu superflua grosseza ayssi cum havem dit.	It is not cut with tweezers nor does it have a sharp end so that it does not harm the vein; and it has great flexibility, for if it were subtle, it would cut the vein due to its subtlety; it has in it superfluous thickness as we have said.
De extraccio venae cruris.	On drawing of the vein of the leg:
Aquesta vena es engendrada en las cambas en terras caudas ayssi cum al- Ategi en terra de Arabics e en las terras de India caudas e aridas de pauca teneritat e en las quals no nays erba ni aybre.	This vein is generated in the legs in warm lands as in Al-Ateji in the land of Arabs and in the warm and arid lands of India with little tenderness, and in which there is no grass nor herb.
E fort leu es engendrada en autres locs del cors otra las cambas.	And it is also generated in other parts of the body other than the legs.
E la gestacio de lu es de putrefaccio que ve dejos la codena ayssi cum venen dedintz le cors serpentz e vermps e scarides e verms engendrantz entre la codena e la carn.	And its generation is from putrefaction that comes underneath the thread as venoms of serpents and worms and maggots and worms generated between the thread and the flesh.
E senhal de la suscepcio de l’adveniment de lu es de aquesta vena que accideys en la camba enflammacio vehement; e aprop le loc es vesicat; e aprop comensa la vena yssir del loc de aquela vesicacio quays sembla razit de planta.	And the sign of the coming of it is from this vein that happens in the leg a violent inflammation; and then the site is blistered; and then the vein begins to emerge from the site of that blister which seems like a plant root.
E adonc cum appar de lu la extremitat, lahoras cove que tu envolvas sobre aquela una pessa de plom del qual sia le pes de una drac. entro a ii drac., e noza aquela e layssa le plom suspendut de la camba.	And then when you see the end of it, you should wrap around it a piece of lead weighing as much as a drachma and hang it from their leg.
E tantas veguadas cum yeys de lu alcuna causa a las partidas defora, envolveys aquo em plom e noza aquel.	And as many times as you see it some cause to the parts outside, wrap that in lead and tie it.
E si mot es prolonguat, lahoras tu inscideys una partida de lu e envolopa le romanent; e no inscidas aquela de razit entro que sia fora yssida, quar si inscideys aquela es contrayta e intra en la carn e fa accidir apostema e poyredura en le loc e ulceracio mala.	And if it is prolonged, then you insert a part of it and wrap the rest; and do not cut that which is rooted so that it is completely extracted, for if you cut it, it will contract and go inside the flesh and cause an abscess and swelling in the site and a bad ulcer.
Per que cove que sia tractada suaument e sia extrayta petit a petit, entro que sia fora-gitada del derier de lu e no remangua de lu alcuna causa en le cors.	So that it may be drawn out gradually and extracted little by little so that it is dripped from the back of him and does not cause harm in him any longer in the body.
E de aquesta vena es yssit en alcus homes que es en la sua longitut de v palms e de detz e ja es pervengut a mi que yssic un de xx palms.	And from this vein it is found in some men that which is in its length of 20 palms and I have seen one of 30 palms.
E si es inscidida en la hora de la sua medicacio, lahoras intromet lo ray en le trauc de lu e perfora aquela am lonc trauc am le cors, entro que sia evacuat tot aquo que es en la materia, e administra putrefaccio del loc per alcus dias am medicinas; e aprop cura aquela per la curacio de apostemas.	And if it is cut in the hour of its medicine, then insert the thread into the vein of him and pierce it with a long piercing through the body so that all that is in the matter is evacuated, and administer putrefaction of the site for several days with medicines; and then cure that with the cure of ulcers.
E aquesta vena alcunas veguadas ha motz ramps, e majorment quan apar a la junctura del pe o en le pe, e veno a lu motz orrificis, e es yssit de quascu orrifici ram.	And this vein sometimes has caused bumps, and mostly when it appears in the joint of the foot or in the foot, and it comes to him bumps orifices, and is generated from each orifice ram.
E donc cura aquela ayssi cum havem dit en la divisio e am aquo que es desus dit.	And therefore cure that as we have said in the division and with that which is above it.
De sectione super vermes generatos sub cute et dicitur aegritudo bovina.	Of a section under worms generated below the skin and is called bovine illness.
Aquesta malautia es nompnada en alcuna terra deves nos malautia bovina per so quar motas veguadas endeve als bious e es verm pauc un le qual es nat entre la codena e la carn, e va en tot le cos pujan e devalan, e es mostrat al sentiment deves le sieu anament de membre en membre entro que disromp la codena e yeys fora.	This illness is named in some land due to a disease of cows because sometimes it happens to them and is called bovine illness because there are worms one of which is generated between the thread and the flesh, and goes throughout all the body, and it appears to feeling due to its motion from member to member so that it breaks the thread and drips out.
E la generacio de lu es per putrefaccio de alcunas humors ayssi cum accideysso verms e serpentz e lombrics e ascaridas en le ventre.	And its generation is from putrefaction of some humors as happens with worms and serpents and roundworms in the belly.
E es temut per la malicia de lu, quar quan el va en le cors e es elevat al cap, e es pervengut al huel, lahoras fort leu uebre en lu e intra e destruzeys le huel, e aquo endeve motas veguadas.	And it is feared for its malice, for when it goes in the body and is elevated to the head, then it causes a strong ache and enters and destroys the brain, and from that sometimes it happens.
E donc quan tu voles curar aquel e extraire lu, lahoras no se fa si no deves la sieua ambulacio e apparacio de lu al sentiment, e adonc cove que tu strenhas aquo que es sobre lu e aquo que es dejos lu am liament e constriccio fort, e aprop secca sobre lu e extratz aquel.	And therefore when you want to cure him and extract it, then do not if he does not feel the pain of it and appear to him to walk and show up to him; and then know that you must tie that which is over him and that which is under him with a ligature and constrict it strongly, and then cut it off and extract it.
E si es preondat en la carn e no le atrobes, lahoras tu pausa cauteri am foc sobre le loc entro que mora, e la major causa que es temuda es corrupcio de lu am la qual corrump le loc ayssi cum havem dit.	And if it is stuck in the flesh and does not go out to you, then put cautery with fire over the site where it lives, and the greater cause that is feared is corruption of it as we have said.
May si tu vezes aquel esser pervengut al cap prop del huel, lahoras strenh sobre le sobrecil am fort strictura, e aprop secsa sobre lu, e extratz aquel; e cove que·l malaute use de mondificacio del sieu cors am medicinas evacuantz humors putridas malas, e guarda se de viandas generantz putrefaccio.	And if you see it come to the head near the brain, then bind over the eyebrow with a strong binding, and cut it off and extract it; and know that the patient abstains from purifying his body of bad putrefied humors.
De sectione super aegritudinem nafir.	Of a section on a cold illness.
Aquesta malautia es nompnada en nostra terra nafir, e es dolor la qual ve en alcus membres, e aprop es permudada de membre en membre.	This illness is named in our land nifer, and it is an ache that comes in some members, and then it is transferred from member to member.
E yeu ja e vista aquela segon que yeu te recomtare.	And I have already seen that according to how you will count them.
Yeu fu apelat a una femna malauta ad una vila, e descubric le sieu bras e vi una imflacio petita en la vena funis del bras, e pus que fu romas per una hora, vi aquela imflacio anar ayssi cum va verm pujan ad aquest, mays pus leugierament que esser por, ayssi cum si fos argent viu quan corr de loc en loc.	And it was called to a woman ill a village, and he discovered her arm and saw a small inflammation in the vein of the arm, and when it came for an hour, he saw that inflammation go as if it were silver when it moved from place to place.
E adonc anet s’en la dolor de aquel loc e fiquet se en le muscle, e aprop aqui stec per una hora.	And then go to the pain in that place and fix it in the muscle, and stay here for an hour.
E aprop correc en l’autre cors entro que pervenc al autre bras.	Then walk around the rest of the body until you reach the other arm.
E aprop recomtec a mi que revolvia se per tot le cors sieu segon que yeu vi; e fo trop meravelat de la permutacio de lu e de la velocitat de membre en membre.	Then I followed him as he moved around the whole body, and I was amazed at his transformation and the speed with which he moved from one member to another.
E yeu ja havia vist denant aquo en les mieus huels segon aquela manieyra, empero yeu he vistz motz les quals atroban dolor esser permutada de membra a membre.	I had seen this before in my own body, but I have also seen pains that travel from one limb to another.
Mays no vi aquo am les huels ayssi cum en la femna.	But I have not seen it happen to the female body.
E yeu no cogiti esser aquo sino que es per aquo quar la femna era de viela, on so de secs cors e de venas descubertas, e en aquesta apparec al sentiment aquela ventositat permutada.	And I did not think it was because of this that the woman was old, but because her body and veins were exposed, and in this case the moving air appeared to the sense as a wind.
E es necessari que no apparesca segon aquesta retro-curacio en aquels que son delicioses e am cors humitz de venas ameguadas.	And it is necessary that this does not appear due to this back-cure in those who are delicate and have humid bodies with hidden veins.
E cum tu voles la curacio de lu, e le pacient sent aquela dolor, lahoras no es a tu aparent al huel ayssi cum havem dit, lahoras tu strenh sobre aquel e dejos lu leugierament e secse sobre aquel entro que sia yssida aquela ventositat coartada, e cauterize le loc.	And when you want to cure him, and the patient feels that pain, then it is not for you to appear in the way we have said, but you should press on him strongly and then release him quickly and put your hand over the area where the wind has been cut off, and cauterize the spot.
Mays si tu no la vezes am los tieus huels, alhoras tu cura aquel am excussio del cors e am aquo que expelleys ventositatz, e carmina aquelas am pillulas fetidas e am pillulas de serapi e semblantz.	But if you do not see it with your own eyes, then you should cure him by emptying the body and by driving out the winds, and those cramps with foul-smelling pills, and with Serapium pills and similar things.
De extraccio de sagetas.	By removing arrows.
Sagetas son diversificadas segon las specias, e segon les locs dels cors en les quals cazo, quar la lor diversitat es que de aquellas so que han grans puntas, e petitas, e concavas, e sordas, so es solidas; e de lor so que han tres angles, e de aquelas a las quals so que han lenguas; e de aquelas a las quals so astelas.	Arrows are diverse according to their species, and according to the parts of the body where they are found, because their diversity is that some have great points, and small, and concaves, and blind, but others are hollow; and some have three angles, while others have tongues, and still others are like stars.
E aquela que es segon les membres e las pessas en las quals cazo es segon dos manieyras: quar les membres o so membres principals concaus, ayssi cum le cervel, le cor, e·l fitge, e le pulmo, e les ronhos, e les budels, e la vezica, e a lor semblantz; e donc quan catz en alcu de aquestz membres e aparo a tu senhals de mort, la qual causa yeu recomtare aprop, lahoras cove que tu evites extraccio de aquela sageta en aquels quar la mort siec aquel en le qual en las majors disposicios, e quan a tu no appareysso aquestz mals senhals, e la sageta no es amaguada en la profunditat del membre, lahoras tu extratz aquela e cura la plagua.	And they are according to the parts and the bones in which they are found according to two ways: for some parts are principal causal parts, like the brain, heart, liver, lung, intestines, bladder, and their likes; therefore when you find one of these parts and sense a sign of death, which I will recount soon, then you should avoid extracting that arrow from those in whom the signs presage death, and when you do not see these ill omens and the arrow is not buried deep in the part, then you should extract it and heal the wound.
E dels senhals del servel es quan catz en lu sageta, e trespassa le os, e es yssit del cyphac le qual es sobre le cervel, quar accideys per lu soda vehement, e scotomia, e vertige, e rogor en les huels, e imflamacio e rogor de la lengua, e spasme e permixtio de entendament e vomi de colera, e fort leu es abscindida la paraula e es destruida la votz, e es yssit del loc de la plagua humiditat blanca semblant a pols, e yeys de lu semblant ad aquositat de la carn.	And the signs of the brain are when you find an arrow in it and it pierces the bone and is stuck in the sphenoid bone which is above the brain, because then occurs violent vomiting and scotomata, and vertigo, and heat in the body, and inflammation and heat in the tongue, and spasms and confusion of the mind and vomiting of bile, and the voice is very hoarse and the speech is destroyed, and there is exudation of white humidity like powder from the wound site, and the eyes look like they are filled with water.
E donc si appareyso a tu aquestz senhals, lahoras tu abste de la curacio e de la extraccio de la sageta, si non es fora.	Therefore, if these signs appear to you, then you should abstain from curing and extracting the arrow unless it is stuck in the body.
Mays les senhals de la sageta quan catz en le cor, so que ela es prop de la mamila senestra, e sent am aquela quays sia ficada en causa dura, e no es causa vueda; e fort leu le movement de la sageta es semblant a movement del pols, e corr de la plagua sanc negra, e siec aquel fregiditat de las extremitatz, e suzor freja, e sincopi; e donc sapias que la mort descen ses tot dopte.	But the signs of the arrow when it pierces the heart are that it is near the left mammilla, and feels like it is stuck in a hard cause, and it is not a soft cause; and the movement of the arrow is very similar to the movement of the pulse, and black blood flows from the wound, and there is frostiness on the extremities, and sweating coldness, and syncope; therefore know that death is approaching quickly.
E les senhals quan la sageta ha plaglat le pulmo so eyssiment de sanc spumos de la plagua, e les vayssels que so prop del col so apostematz, e es mudada la color del malaute, e expira sperit gran aut, e demanda atraccio de ayre freg.	And the signs when the arrow has pierced the lung are exudation of frothy blood from the wound, and the vessels near the neck are swollen, and the color of the patient changes, and they exhale a great amount of spirit, and demand frequent breathing.
E si catz la sageta en le velament le qual es en le pietz, e la dolor lahoras es prop de las costas petitas, e es fayt le ale gran am vehement dolor e am sospir, e no so maugutz totz les membres dels muscles.	And if the arrow pierces the membrane which is in the foot, then the pain will be near the small ribs, and there will be a great wound made with violent pain and sighing, and not all the members of the muscles are affected.
E si catz la sageta en le stomac, lahoras fort leu yeys de la plagua vianda alcuna indigesta.	And if the arrow pierces the stomach, then you will see the wound vomit up some undigested food.
E si catz la sageta en le ventre, e es ficada en lu, yeys alcuna fenda de la plagua, o la tela, o budel le qual es disromput, e no es speransa en la curacio de lu extraccio de la sageta.	And if the arrow pierces the belly and is stuck in it, you will see a wound, or split tissue, or intestine which has been torn, and there is no hope for curing him by extracting the arrow.
E si la sageta catz en la vesica, e es yssida defora urina, e procesesca de lu alcuna causa a las partidas defora, e fort leu es dolor sobre le malaute, lahoras sapias que es mortal.	And if the arrow pierces the bladder and the urine flows out, and some cause processes from the parts outside, and there is strong pain in the body, then know that it is mortal.
Mays les autres membres ayssi cum es la cara, le col, e·l golayro, e las spallas e le adjutori, e les spondils del dos, e la furcula, e la coysa, e la camba e a lor semblantz dels membres, son salvatz segon las majors disposicios quan la sageta no atroba vena ni arteria e no es sageta venenosa.	But the other parts like the face, neck, collarbone, shoulders, vertebrae of the back, breastbone, groin, hip, and their likes of the limbs, are saved according to the best outcome when the arrow does not pierce a vein or artery and is not a poisonous arrow.
E yeu recomtare aquo a tu que he vist del esser de aquestas sagetas, per que signifiques per aquo sobre la curacio tieua.	And I will recount this to you that I have seen from the nature of these arrows so that you may understand through it about your cure.
La qual causa es, quar en un home cazec sageta en le lacrimal del huel de lu en la razitz del nas, e yeu extrayssi aquela a lu del autra partida, dejos le grays de l’aurelha de lu, e es sanat, e no accidic en le huel de lu nocument.	The cause is that in a man who had an arrow shot into his lacrimal gland of the eye in the root of the nose, when I extracted it from the other side, after releasing the muscles of his cheek, he was healed and did not suffer harm to the eye.
E extrayssi autra sageta a un Juzeu la qual cazec en lu en lo grays del sieu huel, dejos la palpebra pus dejos, e la sageta ja era occultada e no so conseguit de aquela sino una petita extremitat am la qual adhereys al sieu fust, e era gran sageta de las sagetas agudas dels Turcs , am ferr leon en la qual no havia aurelhas.	And I extracted another arrow from a Jew who had it shot into his eye in the muscle of the eyelid, after the eyebrow, and the arrow was already concealed and not obtained from that except for a small extremity with which it adhered to his stalk, and it was a great arrow of the acute arrows of the Turks, with lion-wrought iron in which there were no eyebrows.
E senat es le Juzieu , e no accidic en le sieu huel mal accident.	And the Jew was healed, and did not suffer harm to his eye from that ill event.
E extrayssi una autra sageta a un home Crestia la qual era cazuta en le golayro, e era sageta arabica, e es aquela a la qual so aurelhas; e adonc yeu inscidegui sobre aquela entre doas guidegi, e ja era submersa en le golayro de lu; e adonc yeu so subtiliat am aquela, e aprop extraxi aquela, e es sanat le Crestia .	And I extracted another arrow from a Christian who had it shot into his collarbone, and it was an Arabic arrow, and it was the one to which the eyebrows belonged; then I inserted it between two fingers, and it was already submerged in his collarbone; then I made it subtle with that, and I extracted it, and the Christian was healed.
E extraxi autra sageta a un home la qual era cazuta en le sieu ventre, e cogitegui que moris per aquela; e donc, pus que foro passatz xxx dias e no es mudat sobre lu alcuna causa de las suas disposicios, inscidegui sobre la sageta e engenagui sobre aquela, e es sanat, e no accidic a lu accident mal.	And I extracted another arrow from a man who had it shot into his belly, and I thought that he would die from it; then, after thirty days had passed and there was not changed upon him any cause of his disposition, I inserted it and twisted it, and he was healed, and did not suffer harm to him from that ill event.
E vi mays un home en le qual cazec una sageta en le dos de lu, e consolidada es la plagua sobre lu, e pus que foc aprop set ans, yssic la sageta en la razitz de la coyssa.	And I saw a man in whom an arrow was shot into his back, and the wound was healed over him, and after fire had been applied closely for seven years, the arrow was stuck in the root of the groin.
E vi una femna a la qual cazec sageta en le sieu ventre, e la plagua es consolidada dedintz lu, e no es mudada en las suas disposicios en re, e la femna no atrobec nocument en alcunas de las suas opperacios naturals.	And I saw a woman who had an arrow shot into her belly, and the wound was healed over her, and she did not change in her dispositions in the least, and the woman did not suffer harm in any of her natural functions.
E vi un autre home al qual cazec sageta en la sua cara e consolidada es la plagua e romas la sageta, no atrobant aqui mota dolor, e motz semblantz ad aquestz.	And I saw another man in whom an arrow was shot into his face and the wound was healed, but the arrow was not removed, causing no motion of pain, and similar things to these.
E extrayssi la sageta del home dels princeps del rey que era cazuda en le mieg loc del nas sieu e ja havia declinat a la partida dreyta un petit, e occultada era tota la sageta.	And I extracted the arrow from the man of the king's prince who had it shot into the smallest part of his nose, and he had already turned slightly to the right, and the whole arrow was concealed.
E yeu fu appelat a la curacio de lu aprop le cazement de la sageta entro a tres dias.	And I was called to cure him before the extraction of the arrow three days later.
E adonc yeu atrobegui la plagua de la sageta mot streyta; e adonc yeu inquirigui aquela am tenta subtil, e no sentigui aquela; mays el la sentia puncio dejos la aurelha dreyta, e adonc speregui que aquela punccio era per la extremitat de la sageta.	I then found the wound of the arrow very tight; and then I probed it with a subtle probe, and did not feel anything there; but he felt a puncturing pain below the right ear, and then I believed that this puncturing was caused by the tip of the arrow.
E amplastregui le loc am emplaustre en le qual es vertut atrectiva e digestiva, confizant de mi que·l loc se apostemes per que appares a mi le loc de la sageta, per que secces sobre aquela.	And I plastered the location with an ointment containing attractive and digestive virtues, confident that this would dry up the wound and make it appear to me so that I could extract the arrow.
E no accidic en le loc accident significant que la sageta hagues conseguit aquel loc; e yeu continuegui am le emplaustre sobre lu per motz dias e no accidic accident; e consolidada es la plagua entretant, e romas le malaute de la extreccio de lu per spazi de motz dias entro que un jorn sentic la sageta dintz le sieu nas e recontec aquo a mi.	And I did not see any significant accident in the location where the arrow had pierced; and I continued to apply the ointment for many days, and no accident happened; but as the wound healed little by little, and the patient was relieved from his pain due to extraction over a period of several days, one day he felt the arrow tip within his nose, and he recognized this to me.
E adonc yeu pausegui sobre la plagua medicina acuta corrosiva per motz dias entro que foc ubert, e am la tenta yeu assagegui aquel, e atrobegui la extremitat de la sageta subtil, la qual adhereys al fust.	And then I applied a sharp and corrosive medicine to the wound for several days until pus appeared, and probing it with a probe, I found the tip of the arrow, which was adhering to the shaft.
E aprop yeu ajustegui en la apersio de la plagua per aquela medicina acuta entro que apparec a mi visiblament la extremitat de la sageta, e passec a mi temps am aquo per le spazi de temps entro quatre meses.	And then I carefully examined the wound with that sharp medicine until the tip of the arrow appeared visible to me, and it took me some time with this treatment over a period of four months.
E aprop pus que la plagua foc amplificada, e foc a mi possible entrometre las forfexs en lu, e remaure aquela, e no obezic ad eyssiment, lahoras yeu no cessegui subtiliar e ingeniar sobre aquela am manieyras de engen, entro que comensegui un dia sobre aquela am manieyras de engens pendre lu am forceps descentment faytas, segon que vindra la forma de aquelas en la fi del capitol, entro que extraxi aquela; e aprop restauregui aquela plagua.	And then as the wound enlarged, and it was possible for me to insert forceps into it without any obstruction, I did not cease probing and manipulating it with various instruments, until one day I began to manipulate it with specially-made forceps, according to which you will find the form of these in the end of the chapter, and I extracted it; and then I restored that wound.
E alcus metges jutgavan que la cartillage del nas no es restaurada, e yeu restauregui aquela e la plagua es consolidada, e sanat es le malaute per sanetat entiera, e no noguec en lu en deguna causa.	And some doctors judged that the cartilage of the nose was not restored, and I restored it, and the wound healed completely, and the patient recovered entirely without any residue.
E yeu recomti a tu la qualitat de extraccio de alcunas sagetas per que pauses aquo regla e significacio sobre aquo que no he dit, quar las partidas de aquesta art e las difinicios de aquela no so conprehendudas am narracio ni no comprehen aquelas le libre.	And I recommend to you the quality of extraction of some arrows for which you should apply this rule and significance to what I have not said, because the parts of this art and the definitions of that are not comprehended by narration or understanding of the book.
E le artifexs savi compara am pauc sobre mot; e am aquo que es present sobre aquo que es absent; e atroba operacio novela e instrument novel deves le descendement de las causas extranhas del art quan accideysso.	And the wise artisans compare a few things about motion; and what is present to what is absent, and they find new operations and novel instruments the descent of strange causes of the art when it occurs.
E donc yeu dic que sagetas no son fora-gitadas dels membres en les quals son ficadas sino segon dos manieyras: o per atraccio del loc en le qual intrec; o per le contrari de la autra partida.	And therefore I say that arrows are not withdrawn from the parts in which they are placed, but according to two ways, either by attraction of the location in which they enter, or by the contrary of the other part.
E aquela que es gitada per le loc don es intrada, o es sageta procedent en loc carnos, e es atirada e fora-gitada.	And that which is driven by the location from where it entered is an arrow proceeding in a fleshy location, and is thrown and withdrawn.
E si no obezeys a eyssiment de la hora en la qual catz, lahoras cove que tu la laysses per alcus dias entro que poyresca la carn que es al enviro de lu, e sia alleujada l‘atraccio de lu e la sua egressio.	And if it does not obey the exit at the time in which it strikes, then you should leave it for a few days until the flesh around it becomes callused and the attraction of it and its exit are alleviated.
E semblantment si es ficada en os e no obezeys a tu a eyssiment, lahoras layssa aquela per alcus dias e itera aquela am atraccio e mocio en quascun dia, e ja es fora-gitada.	And similarly if it is lodged in the bone and does not obey you to exit, then leave it for a few days and repeat that with attraction and motion every day, and it will be withdrawn.
E si no obezeys a tu eyssiment aprop alcus dias, lahoras cove que tu perforas en le circuit de la sageta en aquel os de tota partida am taravel subtil entro que·l loc sia amplificat de la sageta, e aprop extratz aquela.	And if it does not obey you after a few days, then you should bore into the circumference of the arrow in that bone all around with a subtle tool until the location is enlarged by the arrow, and then extract it.
E si la sageta es ficada en le os del cap e ja ha procezit en un dels ventres del cervel, e apparo en le malaute alcus de aquels accidentz les quals yeu e ditz, lahoras abste de la extraccio de la sageta e layssa aquela entro que·l sieu esser sia equat aprop alcus dias; quar si la sageta perve al ciphac, lahoras la mort no es a lu prolonguada.	And if the arrow is lodged in the bone of the head and has already progressed into one of the ventricles of the brain, and appears in the patient some of those accidents which I have mentioned, then abstain from extracting the arrow and leave it for several days until his being is equilibrated; because if the arrow pierces the brain, then death is not prolonged.
E si la sageta no es ficada sino en le cors del os tant solament e no passa entro al ciphac, e roman le malaute per alcus dias, e no accideys a lu denguna causa de aquels accidentz, lahoras tu engenia en la atraccio de la sageta e en la atraccio de lu.	And if the arrow is not lodged but only in the core of the bone and does not pass within to the brain, and the patient remains for several days without any cause of those accidents happening to him, then you should manipulate both the attraction of the arrow and of him.
Mays si es mot ficada e no obezeys a tu a extraccio, lahoras tu aministra taravels en le circuit de la sageta ayssi cum havem recomtat, e aprop cura le loc entro que sia sanat.	But if it is driven in and does not obey extraction, then you should introduce borings into the circumference of the arrow as we have recommended, and then heal the location until it is restored.
Mays si la sageta ja es amaguada en le loc del cors, e es amaguada del sentiment, lahoras tu inquireys aquela am tenta, e si tu sentas aquela, lahoras atira aquela am alcus sturmentz les quals so convenientz a la atraccio de lu.	But if the arrow is already buried in the location of the body and is buried from sensation, then you should probe it with a probe, and if you feel that, then throw it out with some tools which are convenient to its attraction.
E si no podes sobre lu per la constriccio de la plagua e per la longitut del preon, e aqui no es os ni nervi ni vena, lahoras tu fen sobre la plagua entro que sia amplificada e que sia possible extrayre la sageta.	And if you cannot act upon it due to the constriction of the wound and because of the length of the bone, and there is no bone or nerve or vein there, then you should open the wound until it is enlarged and it is possible to extract the arrow.
E si so a lu aurelhas am las quals sia tenguda, lahoras tu deliura la carn en la qual es ficada de tota partida am tot le engen que poyras far; e ingenia sobre aquo, si no podes sobre la evasio de la carn en la fractura de las aurelhas e en torssio de aquelas entro que obezesca.	And if it is held by the ears through which it is gripped, then you should loosen the flesh in which it is lodged all around with every tool that you can use; and manipulate it if you cannot act upon the opening of the flesh at the fracture of the ears and in twisting them until he obeys.
E quan tu administras la extraccio de la sageta en quascun loc on sia, lahoras tu usa am torcio de la tua ma am forceps a totas partidas entro que fassa aquela obezir; e subtilia am deriera subtilitat que la sageta no sia trencada e que sia fayta a tu dificil atraccio de lu e de aquela extraccio.	And when you administer the extraction of the arrow in whatever location it is in, then you should use twisting of your hand with forceps at all parts until it obeys; and probe it with a subtle probe so that the arrow is not broken and so that you have difficulty extracting it and it has difficulty being extracted.
E si no podes sobre aquela de la tua hora, lahoras tu layssa per alcus dias entro que se poyrescan las partidas que so en le circuit de lu, e aprop itera aquela quar lahoras es alleujada.	And if you cannot act upon it in your hour, then leave it for a few days until the parts which are around it become callused, and then repeat that because by then it will be alleviated.
Mays si a tu fa contrarietat flux de sanc, lahoras tu administra aquo que havem dit de curacio en le sieu capitol.	But if you meet with contrary flow of blood, then you should administer what we have said about healing in its chapter.
E guarda la tua vertut de inscizio de vena o de nervi, o de corda, e aministra engen en tota manieyra a tu possibla de la evasio de la sageta; e fay aquo am facilitat e tranquillitat e tarditat e fermetat ayssi cum yeu e a tu recomtat.	And guard your virtue from cutting of vein or nerve, or tendon, and manipulate it in every way that is possible for you to extract the arrow; and do this with facility and tranquility, and slowness and firmness just as we have recommended to you.
E donc que fassas contrayre la sageta per so que·l malaute sia segon la figura segon la qual foc deves le cazement de la sageta en lu, quar es mays juvatiu.	And therefore contract the arrow so that the patient is according to the figure according to which you should have the position of the arrow in him, for it is more beneficial.
Mays si aquo no es a tu possible, lahoras tu aministra aquo que es a tu possible per las figuras.	But if that is not possible for you, then you should administer what is possible for you according to the figures.
Mays las sagetas que son fora-gitadas per le contrari del autra partida, o que ja de lu procezeys alcuna partida a las partidas de fora, o fa gilbositat la extramitat de la sageta per sentiment de la partida pus desus de la codena propdana e vezes aquela eminent; adonc tu secsa sobre aquela; e sia la seccio segon la quantitat en la qual prenguan las forceps; e aprop atira aquela, quar ela es fayta leugiera a eyssiment.	But the arrows which are withdrawn by the contrary of the other part, or from where some part has already proceeded outward, or make looseness the extremity of the arrow by sensation of the part above the tendon and feel that eminently; then you should probe it; and the section should be according to the quantity in which the forceps take hold of it; and then extract it, for it is easier to obey.
Mays si es retenguda en le os, lahoras tu tortz lama segon contrarietat entro que la sageta enprema en le os, e amplifique a si meteys, e aprop extratz aquela.	But if it is retained in the bone, then you should torture the lamella according to contrary so that the arrow presses upon the bone, and increase it by itself, and then extract it.
E sino, layssa aquela per alcus dias, e aprop itera aquela entro qu’en yesca.	And if not, leave it for a few days, and then repeat that until it is callused.
E si le fust de la sageta es en aquela, lahoras tu impelleys aquela am lu.	And if the shaft of the arrow is in him, then you should push it out by him.
Mays si le fust es cazut e voles aministrar inpulsio, lahoras tu intromet e aquela, si es sorda, sturment concau per so que intre la concavitat de lu en la coa de la sageta e aprop impelleys aquela am lu.	But if the shaft is broken and you want to administer impulsion, then you should introduce it into him, if it is sound, with a tool bent so that it enters the hollow of him in the head of the arrow and then push it out by him.
Mays si la sageta es concava, lahoras tu impelleys aquela am sturment fort intrant en aquela, quar la sageta es alleujada per aquela.	But if the arrow is hollow, then you should push it out with a strong tool by entering into it, for the arrow is alleviated by that.
E si la sageta es entoxiguada, lahoras cove que tu concaves tota la carn en la qual es le vere, si es a tu possible aquo, e aprop cura aquela am aquo que si conveneys.	And if the arrow is poisoned, then you should hollow out all the flesh in which its root is, if it is possible for you to do that, and then heal that with whatever is appropriate.
E si la sageta catz en le pietz, o en le ventre, o en la vesica, o en le costat, e es propinqua per so que tu tocas aquela am la tenta, e es a tu possible secsar sobre aquela, lahoras secsa sobre aquela e guarda te de inscizio de vena o de nervi, e extratz aquela, e aprop cos la plagua si indigeys, e cura aquela entro que sia sanada.	And if the arrow pierces the foot or the belly or the bladder or the side, and is close enough that you can touch it with the probe, and it is possible for you to incise over it, then do so and be wary of vein or nerve, and extract it, and then close the wound if there is bleeding, and treat it until it is healed.
Forma de forceps am las quals so atiradas las sagetas:	Here is a form of forceps by which arrows are extracted:
Sian las extremitatz de lor cum a bec de ausel que son faytas cum serra quan prendon sobre la sageta per so que no la layssen.	Their tips are made like an owl's beak, serrated so that they can grasp the arrow and not let go.
E de aquelas son faytas motas specias, grans, paucas e migieras, segon la quantitat de la grandeza de la sageta e de la sieua pauqueza, e de la amplitud de la plagua, e de la constriccio de lu.	And from these are made many species, large and small, according to the quantity of the size of the arrow and its depth, and the width of the wound, and the constriction of it.
Forma de impellent concau de aquesta extremitat conquava ayssi cum pena de ausel per so que sia alleujat le intrament de la sageta en lu, e impulcio de aquela sorda:	Form of hollow scoop from this concave end like an owl's feather so that the instrument of the arrow in it is eased, and the push of it:
Forma de impellent de sorda extremitat:	Form of push from blunt end:
ayssi cum ray per so que sia alleujat le intrament de lu en la sageta concava e es impellida am aquel.	so that its instrument in the arrow is eased and pushed with that.
De fleubotomia de las venas.	Of phlebotomy of the veins.
Las venas de fleubotomia de las quals corr costuma de fleubotomar so .xxx., de las quals so en le cap .xvi., so es doas venas pulsatils las quals so aprop las aurelhas, dic alhasisain; doas herbas que so en les dos templars apparentz; e doas venas que so en dos lacrimals de dos huels que son appeladas aspicientz; e la vena preparada en le mieg loc del front, e la vena que es en la extremitat del nas; e doas guidegi que so al col; e doas venas que so en la labia desus; e doas venas que so en la labia dejos; e — aquestas so las venas que so appeladas algelic —; e so doas venas que so dejos la lengua.	The veins from which it is customary to phlebotomize are .xxx. [a number] of which there are .xvi. [a number] in the head, and two pulsating veins which are close to the ears, called alhasisain; two herbs which appear on both temples; and two veins in the two lacrimal glands of two holes that are called aspicientz; and the vein prepared in the middle of the forehead, and the vein that is at the end of the nose; and two veins in the neck; and two veins in the upper lip; and two veins in the lower lip; and — these are the veins that are called algelic —; and there are two veins below the tongue.
Mays las venas que so fleubotomadas en les brasses so .v.; quar de aquelas es una cephalica, e es deves le latz silvestre; e le poble appela “la vena del cap”, e sorda, e es vena migiera, e es composta de un ram de la basilica, e de autre ram de la cephalica; e nomna aquela le poble “vena de tot le cors”, e basilica es vena la qual es pausada en le latz domestic, e es nomnada “citillar”, e nompnan aquela les vulguars “vena del ventre”; e funis del bras, e es pausada sobre le focil, e es aquela en la qual es fleubotomat, e es aquela que appar sobre le poutz per apparicio manifesta; e salvatella, e es la vena que es entre lo dit auricular e·l pus petit dit, e so en lu dos ramps.	But the veins that are phlebotomized in the arms are  .v. [a number]; Four of those veins in the arms are   .iv. [a number]; one is a cephalica, and it comes from the wild side; and the people call it  "the vein of the head", and it is blunt, and it is a small vein, and it is composed of a branch of the basilica, and another branch of the cephalica; and they call that   "vena de tot le cors" [vein of all the body], and basilica is a vein which is paused at the domestic side, and is named  “citillar”, and the people name it  "vena del ventre" [vein of the belly]; and the funis of the arm, and it is paused over the elbow, and it is that in which phlebotomy is performed, and it is that one which appears on the wrist from a manifest appearance; and salvatella, and it is the vein between the large auricular vein and the small one, and there are two branches in it.
E en le pe e la camba so tres venas; la una de aquelas es que es dejos la curvatura del denolh del latz silvestre; e la segonda es sophena, e·l loc de lu es dejos la camba del latz domestic; e la vena sciatica, e·l loc de lu es dejos la camba del latz silvestre; e en la camba son autras venas semblantz ad aquelas.	And in the foot and calf there are three veins: one of those is which is below the curvature of the jaw of the wild side; and the second is sophena, and its location is below the calf of the domestic side; and sciatica vein, and its location is below the calf of the wild side; and there are other similar veins in the calf.
Le juvament de las venas que so aprop las aurelhas es a cataris antics e emigranea e sahafati e ulceracios del cap malas antiquas.	The opening of the veins which are close to the ears is for ancient catarrh and emigration and old ulcers in the head.
E la qualitat de sagnar aquelas es segon que yeu recomti a tu: es que sia ras le cap del malaute, e sia freguat le cap del malaute en le occipiti en le loc de amdoas las venas am drap ample am bona fricacio; aprop strenha le malaute le sieu col am una benda entro que apparan las doas e les locs de lor so aprop las aurelhas en dos locs depremegutz del cap; e quereys aquela am le tieu dit, e si tu sentes le pols de aquelas am le dit tieu, aqui senha am tenta.	And the quality of bleeding them is according to what you see: it is that you wash the head of the patient, and rub the head of the patient in the occiput at the places where both veins are with a wide bandage so that there is good friction; then tighten the patient's neck with a bandage so that the two ears appear on both sides of the head in two spots which are depressed from the head; and feel those with your finger, and if you feel their pulses with your finger, here is a probe.
Aprop tu pren la lancea cutellar, e es aquela que es inscident, e aprop tu intromet aquel dejos la vena en la codena entro que·l fleubotomi vengua al os.	Then you take the cutting lance, and it is that which pierces, and then you insert it under the vein in the bone where the phlebotomy comes from the bone.
E aprop eleva la tua ma am la vena e la codena a las partidas desus e inscideys la vena am inscizio inscident.	And then lift your hand with the vein and the bone to the parts above, and pierce the vein with piercing incision.
E sia la longitut de la inscizio la quantitat de dos ditz ajustatz o entorn de aquo; e fay yssir del sanc atant quant voles.	And let the length of the incision be the quantity of two fingers' widths or around that; and make the blood come out as much as you want.
E aprop strenh am pulvils e layssa aquela entro que sia sanada.	Then tighten it with powder and leave it so that it heals.
E ja e precedit en le comensament del libre la inscizio de aquelas e de lor la cauterizacio.	And see in the beginning of the book the incision of those and their cauterization.
